014package org.jdbi.v3.postgres;
015
016import java.lang.reflect.Type;
017import java.time.Period;
018import java.util.Optional;
019
020import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.ConfigRegistry;
021import org.jdbi.v3.core.mapper.ColumnMapper;
022import org.jdbi.v3.core.mapper.ColumnMapperFactory;
023import org.postgresql.util.PGInterval;
024
025/**
026 * A column mapper which maps Postgres's {@link PGInterval} type to Java's {@link Period}.
027 *
028 * <p>
029 * Not all {@link PGInterval}s are representable as {@link Period}s. E.g., one with minutes. An
030 * {@link IllegalArgumentException} will be thrown in this case.
031 */
032public class PeriodColumnMapperFactory implements ColumnMapperFactory {
033    @Override
034    public Optional<ColumnMapper<?>> build(Type type, ConfigRegistry config) {
035        if (type != Period.class) {
036            return Optional.empty();
037        }
038        return Optional.of((r, i, c) -> {
039            final Object obj = r.getObject(i);
040            if (obj == null) {
041                return null;
042            }
043            if (!(obj instanceof PGInterval)) {
044                throw new IllegalArgumentException(String.format("got non-pginterval %s", obj));
045            }
046            final PGInterval interval = (PGInterval) obj;
047            if (interval.getHours() != 0 || interval.getMinutes() != 0 || interval.getSeconds() != 0) {
048                throw new IllegalArgumentException(
049                        String.format("pginterval \"%s\" is too granular to be represented as period",
050                                interval.getValue()));
051            }
052            return Period.of(interval.getYears(), interval.getMonths(), interval.getDays());
053        });
054    }
055}
